description: Borrowed from Middle Dutch vieren (“to slacken”).

verbs.description: veer (third-person singular simple present veers, present participle veering, simple past and past participle veered)

entries.meaning: (obsolete, nautical) To let out (a sail-line), to allow (a sheet) to run out.
A turn or swerve; an instance of veering.
examples: […]  there is always a sudden, though small rise in the barometer, and a sudden drop of temperature of several degrees, sometimes as much as ten or fifteen degrees; there is also a sudden veer in the wind direction.

verbs.description: veer (third-person singular simple present veers, present participle veering, simple past and past participle veered)

entries.meaning: (intransitive) To change direction or course suddenly; to swerve.
examples: The car slid on the ice and veered out of control.

entries.meaning: (intransitive, of the wind) To shift in a clockwise direction (if in the Northern Hemisphere, or in a counterclockwise direction if in the Southern Hemisphere).
examples: It is clear that when a front passes the observer, there must be a sudden shift in wind: in the northern hemisphere it will always  veer, that is, shift in a clockwise sense.

entries.meaning: (intransitive, nautical, of the wind) To shift aft.
(intransitive, nautical) To change direction into the wind; to wear ship.
